Award.AwardTitle: AF: Small: Topological Data Analysis for Big and High Dimensional Data

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The computing community is increasingly facing the challenge of processing and interpreting huge amounts of data that is being generated all around us by personal devices, digital sensors, data centers, scientific studies, and social networks. The nature of this data is usually high dimensional, that is, when interpreted as points, they reside in an high dimensional Euclidean space. The curse of `dimensionality' together with `size' puts up a formidable challenge to decipher knowledge from them in a principled way. Among the various approaches proposed to `mine' this data, topological approaches are emerging as robust and global methods that could complement the other approaches, be it statistical or geometrical. How can one deal with the difficulty of `big' data by developing new algorithms in computational topology and geometry is the focus of this proposal. The proposed research aims to investigate three techniques, namely, subsampling, localization, and simplicial collapse to handle the menace of `size' and `dimension'. This requires developing innovative computational tools grounded in algorithmic theory and mathematics from algebraic topology, analysis, and discrete geometry.

The proposed topological methods would enhance the understanding of `big' data in general which could originate from images in the medical fields, videos of some events, trends in finance, or connectivities in social networks. The goal is to produce practical algorithms that can be turned into usable software which would be useful for both academia and industry. Other than standard academic forums, there are plans to disseminate the results from this project through course notes, tutorials, and web-pages to reach wider audience. The PI also plans to develop course materials on topological data analysis that will include results obtained in the project. The support from the project will train graduate students. Efforts will be made to recruit students from under-represented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project we focused on how to reduce data and structures (simplicial complexes) built on top of it so that computation for topological data analysis (TDA) becomes less expensive. One of the main bottlenecks of applying otherwise robust tools from TDA is that it is computationally more expensive than other data analysis techniques. We attacked the problem from different directions. In one line of work, we proposed how to decimate the input data without sacrificing quality of analysis. This gave rise to declutter and resample technique and also a sample sparsification technique that we have reported in published papers. In another line of work, we proposed an algorithm to sparsify a Rips filtration that are used for computing topological features. This gave rise to what we named as the SimBa technique. A software based on this result has been released for public use.

For complex data, our main approach has been to compute simplified structures out of them. One structure is Reeb graph which summarizes a functional data with a graph structure. We designed algorithms to compare such structures and also implemented a software based on the result. A well known TDA technique known for data exploration is called MAPPER. We extended MAPPER to a multiscale version that has enabled further study of data with the MAPPER technique.

Several graduate students (Three Phd students and a Masters student) have been supported by the project. They all got trained in designing efficient algorithms, mastering concepts from algebraic topology, and producing quality software. One of the students was a female who is about to finish her Phd. Several software came out of the project. One of these software called SIMBA has been used by several researchers in the field of TDA. Several websites containing the results of the project have been developed. The PI has incorporated some of the findings from the project in his newly developed course on TDA. There is a plan to write a book on the topic of TDA which will include several results obtained in this project.
